long zgbmatrix::zgbsv (  zgematrix &  mat  )  [inline]
 

solve A*X=Y using zgbsv
The argument is zgematrix Y. Y is overwritten and become the solution X. A is also overwritten.

zgbmatrix & zgbmatrix::operator+= (  const zgbmatrix &  mat  )  [inline]
 

zgbmatrix+=zgbmatrix operator
If the band width of the left side matrix is narrower than the right side matrix, the band width of the left side matrix become thicker as same as the right side matrix.

Definition at line 24 of file zgbmatrix-zgbmatrix.hpp.

00068   std::cerr << "# [MARK] operator*(const zssmatrix&, const zgbmatrix&)"
00069             << std::endl;
00070 #endif//CPPL_VERBOSE
00071   
00072 #ifdef  CPPL_DEBUG
00073   if(matA.N!=matB.M){
00074     std::cerr << "[ERROR] operator*(const zssmatrix&, const zgbmatrix&)"
00075               << std::endl
00076               << "These two matrises can not make a product." << std::endl
00077               << "Your input was (" << matA.M << "x" << matA.N << ") * ("
00078               << matB.M << "x" << matB.N << ")." << std::endl;
00079     exit(1);
00080   }
00081 #endif//CPPL_DEBUG
00082   
00083   zgematrix newmat( matA.M, matB.N );
00084   newmat.zero();
00085   
00086   for(long c=0; c<matA.VOL; c++){
00087     for(long k=max(0,matA.Jndx[c]-matB.KU);
00088         k<min(matB.M,matA.Jndx[c]+matB.KL+1); k++){
00089       newmat(matA.Indx[c],k) += matA.Array[c]*matB(matA.Jndx[c],k);
00090     }
00091   }
00092   
00093   return _(newmat);
00094 }
